{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Stella Adler | image = Stella Adler in Shadow of The Thin Man trailer.jpg | caption = Adler in ''[[Shadow of the Thin Man]]'' (1941) | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1901|2|10}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1992|12|21|1901|2|10}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Mount Carmel Cemetery (Queens, New York)|Mount Carmel Cemetery]], [[Queens]] | occupation = Actress | yearsactive = 1919–1952 |spouse={{Plainlist| * Horace Eliascheff
(m.19??; div. 19??) * {{marriage|[[Harold Clurman]]|1943|1960|end=divorced}} * [[Mitchell A. Wilson]]
(m. 19??; d. 1973) }} | children = 1 }} '''Stella Adler''' (February 10, 1901 – December 21, 1992)Stella Adler Feb 10, 1901 – Dec 21, 1992 (New York, New York, NY) 563-22-9174 California; [[Social Security Death Index]] was an American actress and acting teacher.[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/09/theater/09adler.html?_r=1 A New Act Unfolds in Drama Dynasty] ''[[The New York Times]]'', April 9, 2008 She founded the [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]] in New York City in 1949.{{cite web |url=https://stellaadler.com/about/}} Later in life she taught part time in Los Angeles, with the assistance of protégée, actress [[Joanne Linville]]{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jun/29/entertainment/et-stella-adler29 |title=A Stella Adler turf war in L.A.}}, who continues to teach Adler's technique.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE0DD1E31F931A15751C1A964958260 Stella Adler, 91, an Actress And Teacher of the Method] ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 22, 1992.[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/6078/Stella-Adler Stella Adler] ''[[Britannica.com]]''. Her grandson Tom Oppenheim now runs the school in New York City, which has produced alumni such as [[Marlon Brando]], [[Robert De Niro]], [[Harvey Keitel]], [[Elaine Stritch]], [[Kate Mulgrew]], [[Kipp Hamilton]], and [[Jenny Lumet]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0525886/|title=Jenny Lumet|work=imdb.com}} [[Irene Gilbert]], a longtime protégée and friend, ran the Stella Adler Academy of Acting and Theatre in Los Angeles, until her death.{{cite web|url=http://www.stellaadler-la.com|title=Stella Adler Academy of Acting Los Angeles|work=stellaadler-la.com}} The Los Angeles school continues to function as an acting studio and houses several theaters. Alumni of the Stella Adler-Los Angeles school include [[Mark Ruffalo]], [[Benicio Del Toro]], [[Brion James]], [[Salma Hayek]], [[Clifton Collins Jr.]], and [[Sean Astin]]. == Early life == Stella Adler was born in the [[Lower East Side]] of New York City.[https://books.google.com/books?id=WSaMu4F06AQC&pg=PA10&dq=Stella+Adler+-inauthor:%22Stella+Adler%22&lr=&as_brr=0#PPA9,M1 Adler Stella] ''Notable American Women: A Biographical Dictionary Completing the Twentieth Century'', by Susan Ware, Stacy Lorraine Braukman, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. Harvard University Press, 2004. {{ISBN|0-674-01488-X}}. pp. 9–10 She was the youngest daughter of [[Sara Adler|Sara]] and [[Jacob P. Adler]], the sister of [[Luther Adler|Luther]] and [[Jay Adler]], and half-sister of Charles Adler and Celia Adler, star of the Yiddish Theater. All five of her siblings were actors. The Adlers comprised the Jewish-American Adler acting dynasty, which had its start in the [[Yiddish Theater District]] and was a significant part of the vibrant ethnic theatrical scene that thrived in New York from the late 19th century to the 1950s. Adler became the most famous and influential member of her family. She began acting at the age of four as a part of the Independent Yiddish Art Company of her parents. == Career == Adler began her acting career at the age of four in the play ''Broken Hearts'' at the Grand Street Theatre on the Lower East Side, as a part of her parents' [[Yiddish theatre#Yiddish theater in the Americas|Independent Yiddish Art Company]].{{cite book |title=The Great Acting Teachers and Their Methods |last=Brestoff |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Brestoff |year=1995 |publisher=[[Smith & Kraus]] |isbn=978-1-57525-012-0 }} She grew up acting alongside her parents, often playing roles of boys and girls. Her work schedule allowed little time for schooling, but when possible, she studied at public schools and [[New York University]]. She made her London debut, at the age of 18, as Naomi in ''Elisa Ben Avia'' with her father's company, in which she appeared for a year before returning to New York. In London, she met her first husband, Englishman Horace Eliashcheff; their brief marriage, however, ended in a divorce. Adler made her English-language debut on Broadway in 1922 as the Butterfly in ''The World We Live In'', and she spent a season in the [[vaudeville]] circuit. In 1922–23, the renowned [[Russians|Russian]] actor-director [[Konstantin Stanislavski]] made his only U.S. tour with his [[Moscow Art Theatre]]. Adler and many others saw these performances, which had a powerful and lasting impact on her career and the 20th-century American theatre. She joined the [[American Laboratory Theatre]] in 1925; there, she was introduced to Stanislavski's theories, from founders and Russian actor-teachers and former members of the [[Moscow Art Theater]]—[[Richard Boleslavsky]] and [[Maria Ouspenskaya]]. In 1931, with [[Sanford Meisner]] and [[Elia Kazan]], among others, she joined the [[Group Theatre (New York)|Group Theatre]], New York, founded by [[Harold Clurman]], [[Lee Strasberg]], and [[Cheryl Crawford]], through theater director and critic, Clurman, whom she later married in 1943. With Group Theatre, she worked in plays such as ''Success Story'' by John Howard Lawson, two [[Clifford Odets]] plays, ''[[Awake and Sing!]]'' and ''[[Paradise Lost]]'', and directed the touring company of Odets's ''Golden Boy'' and ''More to Give to People''. Members of Group Theatre were leading interpreters of the method acting technique based on the work and writings of Stanislavski. In 1934, Adler went to Paris with Harold Clurman and studied intensively with Stanislavski for five weeks. During this period, she learned that Stanislavski had revised his theories, emphasizing that the actor should create by imagination rather than memory. Upon her return, she broke away from Strasberg on the fundamental aspects of method acting.''Twentieth Century Actor Training: Principles of Performance'', by Alison Hodge. Routledge, 2000. {{ISBN|0-415-19451-2}}. p. 139 In January 1937, Adler moved to Hollywood. There, she acted in films for six years under the name Stella Ardler, occasionally returning to the Group Theater until it dissolved in 1941. Eventually, she returned to New York to act, direct, and teach, the latter first at [[Erwin Piscator]]'s [[Dramatic Workshop]] at the [[New School for Social Research]], New York City,[https://books.google.com/books?id=oR_4rVfE438C&pg=PA14&dq=Stella+Adler+-inauthor:%22Stella+Adler%22&lr=&as_brr=0#PPA15,M1 Stella Adler] ''Great Jewish Women'', by Elinor Slater, Robert Slater. Published by Jonathan David Company, Inc., 1994. {{ISBN|0-8246-0370-2}}. pp. 14–16. before founding [[Stella Adler Studio of Acting]] in 1949. In the following years, she taught [[Marlon Brando]], [[Judy Garland]], [[Elizabeth Taylor]], [[Dolores del Río]], [[Lena Horne]], [[Robert De Niro]], [[Elaine Stritch]], [[Martin Sheen]], [[Manu Tupou]], [[Harvey Keitel]], [[Melanie Griffith]], [[Peter Bogdanovich]], and [[Warren Beatty]], among others, the principles of characterization and script analysis. She also taught at the New School,[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE2D81E3AF937A3575AC0A96E948260 Theater; Stella Adler In Her Latest Role: Author] ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 4, 1988. and the [[Yale School of Drama]]. For many years, Adler led the undergraduate drama department at New York University,[http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/research/fa/adler.stella.bio.html Stella Adler (1901–1992) – Biographical Sketch] ''[[Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center]], University of Texas at Austin. and became one of America's leading acting teachers.
Stella Adler was much more than a teacher of acting. Through her work she imparts the most valuable kind of information—how to discover the nature of our own emotional mechanics and therefore those of others. She never lent herself to vulgar exploitations, as some other well-known so-called "methods" of acting have done. As a result, her contributions to the [[Presentational acting and Representational acting|theatrical culture]] have remained largely unknown, unrecognized, and unappreciated.Adler, Stella. [https://books.google.com/books?id=i6rE7ocYWngC&pg=PA7 "Preface"]. ''[[Presentational acting and Representational acting|The Art of Acting]]''. [[Applause]], Canada: 2000. :—Marlon Brando
In 1988, she published ''The Technique of Acting'' with a foreword by Marlon Brando. From 1926 until 1952, she appeared regularly on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. Her later stage roles include the 1946 revival of ''He Who Gets Slapped'' and an eccentric mother in the 1961 black comedy ''Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mama's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' So Sad''. Among the plays she directed was a 1956 revival of the Paul Green/Kurt Weill antiwar musical ''Johnny Johnson''.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwVlkTBSCugC&pg=PA1&dq=Stella%20Adler%20-inauthor:%22Stella%20Adler%22&lr=&as_brr=0#PPA1,M1|title=Acting Now: Conversations on Craft and Career|first=Edward|last=Vilga|date=January 1, 1997|publisher=Rutgers University Press|via=Google Books}} She appeared in only three films: ''Love on Toast'' (1937), ''[[Shadow of the Thin Man]]'' (1941), and ''My Girl Tisa'' (1948). She concluded her acting career in 1961, after 55 years. During that time, and for years after, she became a renowned acting teacher. == Stanislavski and the method == {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2012}} Adler was one of the few American actors to study with Konstantin Stanislavski. She was a prominent member of the Group Theatre, but differences with [[Lee Strasberg]] over the [[Stanislavski's system]] (later developed by Strasberg into [[method acting]]) made her leave the group. She once said: "Drawing on the emotions I experienced — for example, when my mother died — to create a role is sick and schizophrenic. If that is acting, I don't want to do it." Adler met with Stanislavski again later in his career and questioned him on Strasberg's interpretation. He told her that he had abandoned emotional memory, which had been Strasberg's dominant paradigm, but that they both believed that actors did not have what is required to play a variety of roles already instilled inside them, and that extensive research was needed to understand the experiences of characters who have different values originating from different cultures. Like Stanislavski, Adler understood the "gold hidden" inside the circumstances of the text. Actors should stimulate emotional experience by imagining the scene's "given circumstances," rather than recalling experiences from their own lives. She also understood that 50% of the actors job is internal (imagination, emotion, action, will) and 50% is externals (characterization, way of walking, voice, fencing, sports). To find what works for the character, the actors must study the circumstances of the text and make their choices based on what one gets from the material. For instance, if a character talks about horse riding, one needs to know something about horse riding as an actor, otherwise one will be faking. More importantly, one must study the values of different people to understand what situations would have meant to people, when those situations might mean nothing in the actor's own culture. Without this work, Adler said that an actor walks onto the stage "naked". This approach is one for which both Marlon Brando and Robert De Niro became famous. Adler also trained actors' sensory imagination to help make the characters' experiences more vivid. She believed that mastery of the physical and vocal aspects of acting was necessary for the actor to command the stage, and that all body language should be carefully crafted and voices need to be clear and expressive. She often referred to this as an actor's "size" or "worthiness of the stage". Her biggest mantra was perhaps "in your choices lies your talent", and she encouraged actors to find the most grand character interpretation possible in a scene; another favorite phrase of hers regarding this was "don't be boring". Singer-songwriter [[Janis Ian]] studied under Adler in the early 1980s to help her feel more comfortable on stage, and the two women remained close friends until Adler's death. In her autobiography ''Society's Child'' (2008), Ian recalled that Adler had little patience for students who weren't progressing as she wanted, going so far on one occasion as to give one of her students a dime and tell her to call her mother to pick her up because "she had no business in the theater." On another occasion, Ian relates, Adler forcibly ripped a dress off another actress's body to get the actress to play a scene a different way. Devo Cutler-Rubenstein credits Stella Adler for inspiring her that a character is made real through one's imagination. She cites a story when she studied with Stella Adler who slowly peeled her bra off under her clothes, while lecturing about Tennessee Williams in Los Angeles, "You listened to me, didn't you, because you were fascinated with what I was doing with my bra?" Devo says Stella insisted on the truth living in our imagination and that was "unending pool of information and research to be accessed." == Personal life == Adler married three times, first to Horace Eliascheff, the father of her only child Ellen, then from 1943 to 1960 to director and critic [[Harold Clurman]], one of the founders of the Group Theatre. She was finally married to [[physics|physicist]] and novelist [[Mitchell A. Wilson]], who died in 1973. From 1938 to 1946, she was sister-in-law to actress [[Sylvia Sidney]]. Sidney was married to her brother Luther at the time and provided Stella with a nephew. Even after Sidney and Luther divorced, she and Sylvia remained close friends. == Death == On December 21, 1992, Adler died from [[heart failure]] at the age of 91 in Los Angeles. She was survived by her daughter Ellen, her sister Julia, and two grandchildren, including Tom Oppenheim, current president and artistic director of the Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York. She was interred in the Mount Carmel Cemetery in [[Glendale, Queens|Glendale, New York]]. == Legacy == Adler's technique, based on a balanced and pragmatic combination of imagination and memory, is hugely credited with introducing the subtle and insightful details and a deep physical embodiment of a character. Elaine Stritch once said: "What an extraordinary combination was Stella Adler—a goddess full of magic and mystery, a child full of innocence and vulnerability." In the book ''Acting: Onstage and Off'', [[Robert Barton (actor)|Robert Barton]] wrote: "[Adler] established the value of the actor putting himself in the place of the character rather than vice versa ... More than anyone else, Stella Adler brought into public awareness all the close careful attention to text and analysis Stanislavski endorsed."{{cite book|last=Barton|first=Robert|title=Acting: Onstage and Off|year=2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=0-495-89886-4|pages=136–7}} In 1991, Stella Adler was inducted into the [[American Theater Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/06/theater/on-stage-and-off.html|title=On Stage, and Off|publisher=New York Times|date=December 6, 1991}} In 2004, the [[Harry Ransom Center]] at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] acquired Adler's complete archive along with a small collection of her papers from her former husband [[Harold Clurman]]. The collection includes correspondence, manuscripts, typescripts, lecture notes, photographs, and other materials.{{Cite web|url=http://norman.hrc.utexas.edu/fasearch/findingAid.cfm?eadid=00504|title=Stella Adler and Harold Clurman: An Inventory of their Papers in the Performing Arts Collection at the Harry Ransom Center|website=norman.hrc.utexas.edu|access-date=2017-03-15}} Over 1,100 audio and video recordings of Adler teaching from the 1960s to the 1980s have been digitized by the Center and are accessible on site. The archive traces her career from her start in the New York [[Yiddish Theater District]] to her encounters with Stanislavski and the Group Theatre to her lectures at the Stella Adler Studio of Acting.[http://www.utexas.edu/news/2004/04/26/nr_hrc-2/ Ransom Center acquires Stella Adler archive] The University of Texas at Austin, April 26, 2004. In 2006, she was honored with a posthumous [[List of stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame|star]] on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in front of the Stella Adler Theatre at 6773 Hollywood Boulevard.[http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2006Aug04/0,4670,PeopleStellaAdler,00.html Adler Gets Posthumous Hollywood Walk Star] ''[[Fox News]]'', Friday, August 4, 2006. == Stella Adler schools == {{Main article|Stella Adler Studio of Acting}} The acting schools Adler founded still operate today in New York City and Los Angeles. Her method, based on use of the actor's imagination, has been studied by actors such as Robert De Niro, Elaine Stritch, [[Martin Sheen]], [[Diana Muldaur]], [[Dolores del Rio]], [[Bob Crane]], [[Roy Scheider]], [[Vincent D'Onofrio]], [[Mark Ruffalo]], [[Warren Beatty]], [[Michael Imperioli]], [[Salma Hayek]], [[Sean Astin]], [[Barbara Stuart]], [[Joyce Meadows]], [[Stephen Bauer]], [[Judd Nelson]], [[Christoph Waltz]], [[Benicio del Toro]], and [[Marlon Brando]], who served as the New York studio's honorary chairman until his death and was replaced by Warren Beatty. The Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York opened a new studio in Los Angeles named the Art of Acting Studio in 2010 and is run by the Adler family. == Career on Broadway == All works are the original Broadway productions unless otherwise noted. * ''The Straw Hat'' (1926) * ''Big Lake'' (1927) * ''The House of Connelly'' (1931) * ''1931'' (1931) * ''Night Over Taos'' (1932) * ''Success Story'' (1932) * ''Big Night'' (1933) * ''Hilda Cassidy'' (1933) * ''Gentlewoman'' (1934) * ''Gold Eagle Guy'' (1934) * ''[[Awake and Sing!]]'' (1935) * ''[[Paradise Lost (play)|Paradise Lost]]'' (1935) * ''Sons and Soldiers'' (1943) * ''Pretty Little Parlor'' (1944) * ''[[He Who Gets Slapped]]'' – [[Revival (play)|revival]] (1946) * ''Manhattan Nocturne'' (1943) * ''Sunday Breakfast'' (1952) == Works == * ''The Fervent Years: The Group Theatre and the Thirties'', By Harold Clurman, Stella Adler. [[Da Capo Press]], 1983. {{ISBN|0-306-80186-8}}. * ''The Technique of Acting'', by Stella Adler. Bantam Books, 1988. {{ISBN|0-553-05299-3}}. * ''Creating a Character: A Physical Approach to Acting'', by Moni Yakim, Muriel Broadman, Stella Adler. Applause Books, 1993. {{ISBN|1-55783-161-0}}. * ''Stella Adler: The Art of Acting'', by Stella Adler, Howard Kissel, Applause Books, 2000. {{ISBN|1-55783-373-7}}. * ''Stella Adler on Ibsen, Strindberg, and Chekhov'', by Stella Adler, Barry Paris. Random House Inc, 2001. {{ISBN|0-679-74698-6}}. * ''Stella Adler on America's Master Playwrights: Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Clifford Odets, William Saroyan, Tennessee Williams, William Inge, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee'', by Stella Adler, Barry Paris (editor). Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-679-42443-7}}. == Quotes == * "In your choices lies your talent." * "Never explain, never complain." * "Don't use your conscious past. Use your creative imagination to create a past that belongs to your character. I don't want you to be stuck with your own life. It's too little." * "You can't be boring. Life is boring. The weather is boring. Actors must not be boring." * "The word "theatre" comes from the Greeks. It means the seeing place. It is the place people come to see the truth about life and the social situation. The theatre is a spiritual and social X-ray of its time. The theatre was created to tell people the truth about life and the social situation." * "Life beats down and crushes the soul and art reminds you that you have one." * "The play is not in the words, it's in you!"{{cite web|url=http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/authors/s/stella_adler.html#ixzz1I6dujrA9|title=Stella Adler Quotes – BrainyQuote|work=brainyquote.com}} * "Rehearsal without full energy is a lie." == See also == * [[Michael Chekhov]] * [[Uta Hagen]] * [[Estelle Harman]] * [[Robert Lewis (actor)|Robert Lewis]] * [[Lee Strasberg]] * [[Sanford Meisner]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Wikiquote}} {{Commons}} * {{IBDB name}} * {{IMDb name|0012245}} * {{Rotten-tomatoes-person|stella_adler|Stella Adler}} * [http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/adler-stella Stella Adler], Jewish Women Encyclopedia * [http://www.stellaadler-la.com/ Stella Adler Los Angeles] * [http://www.stellaadler.com/ Stella Adler Studio of Acting] * [http://norman.hrc.utexas.edu/fasearch/findingAid.cfm?eadid=00504 The Stella Adler and Harold Clurman archive] at the [[Harry Ransom Center]], [[University of Texas at Austin]] * [http://archives.nypl.org/the/18375 Irene Gilbert and Stella Adler papers, circa 1959–1998 (bulk 1970–1992)], The Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]] * [http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/a/stella_adler/index.html Stella Adler News] at ''[[The New York Times]]'' {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Adler, Stella}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:American stage actresses]] [[Category:Jewish American actresses]] [[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:Acting theorists]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Actresses from New York City]] [[Category:Yiddish theatre performers]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American Theater Hall of Fame inductees]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}}
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name = Student Police Cadet Kerala |image = [[Image:Student police cadet logo.JPG|Student പോലീസ് Logo|150px]] |role = |size = |equipment = |garrison = [[Thiruvananthapuram]] |garrison_label = Headquarters |motto = |website = http://www.studentpolicecadet.org |current_commander = |current_commander_label = |identification_symbol = |dates = 27 August 2010 |battle_honours = }} The '''Student Police Cadet (SPC) Project''' is a school-based initiative by [[Kerala Police]], implemented jointly by the Departments of Home and Education, and supported by Departments of Transport, Forest, Excise and Local Self-Government. The project trains high school students to respect the law, practice discipline and civic sense, and develop empathy for vulnerable sections of society. It also strengthens commitment towards family, community, and the environment, enabling them to resist negative tendencies such as substance abuse, deviant behavior, intolerance, and other social evils.
The Project was launched on 2 August 2010 in 127 high schools/higher secondary schools across [[Kerala]],<ref>Biju Govind [http://www.hindu.com/2010/08/02/stories/2010080257040700.htm] "VS to launch Student Police Cadet Project" ''The Hindu'' 2 August 2010</ref> with 11176 students, both boys and girls, enrolled as Cadets and 254 teachers trained as school-level Community Police Officers (CPOs).<ref>"126 teachers to become Community Police Officers" [http://www.hindu.com/2010/11/14/stories/2010111458400300.htm], "The Hindu" 14 November 2010</ref> In 2012, the project was expanded to cover a total of 249 high schools across Kerala,<ref>[http://www.keralacm.gov.in/index.php/home/34-frontslider/711-student-police-cadet-to-be-extended-to-100-more-schools-cm]"student-police-cadet-to-be-extended-to-100-more-schools" ''Official website of Chief Minister of Kerala''</ref> with a combined strength of nearly 16,000 SPCs and 500 CPOs.
==Genesis== The program has its roots in Janakeeyam, a community-level initiative by [[Kochi]] City police, in 2006. During the event, more than 400 high school students from 30 local schools interacted with police officers, engaging in wide-ranging discussions on community issues and visiting police stations. During these discussions, the students expressed a desire to have a permanent arrangement for ongoing communication with the police. Accordingly, a pilot Student-Police project was launched on an experimental basis in a few selected schools .<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2009/12/07/stories/2009120754320400.htm] "State mulling Student Police Cadet", N J Nair, ''The Hindu'', 7 December 2009</ref>
Subsequently, at Kozhikode in January 2010, a squad of specially trained high school students was entrusted with the responsibility of crowd management at [[Kerala School Youth Festival]], Asia's largest youth-focused cultural festival involving more than 10,000 participants. Following the successful execution of this task by the cadets, and in light of the success stories from project-implemented schools, a detailed proposal for a statewide school-based training programme was prepared under the guidance of Sri '''[[Jacob Punnoose]]''' IPS (DGP-Kerala) and submitted to the Government of Kerala. On the basis of this report, Government of Kerala issued GO (P)121/2010/Home dated 29 May 2010, with the stated objective of moulding a generation of law-abiding, socially committed and service-oriented youth. A state-level Advisory Committee was constituted with Sri. Jacob Punnoose IPS (DGP-Kerala) as chairman, senior Government officials as members, and Sri '''[[P Vijayan]]''' IPS as State Nodal Officer for the SPC Project.
==Features== * The SPC Project is an association between the educational and law enforcement authorities in a community. * The project is composed of a structured two-year training programme to develop students as responsible citizens who manifest respect for the law, civic sense, empathy for vulnerable sections of society, and resistance to social evils as lifelong personal habits. * The project creates youth willing to react against social evils by ensuring safe and healthy academic environments, drug-and narcotic-free premises and reinforcement of positive values among students in schools. * The project stimulates parents and community leaders to work in cooperation with law enforcement authorities to create safe and healthy communities * The project catalyses community-level activities to promote better use of natural resources, by encouraging habits that are minimally harmful to the environment. * The project makes use of existing law enforcement infrastructure to promote the physical, psychological and educational development of youth.
The SPC project seeks to deepen the social democratic fabric of communities by evolving young minds into enlightened citizens who obey laws not by enforcement but rather as a natural and rational act. The Student Police Cadet Project does not create more policemen, instead it seeks to grow the policeman within each young member of their communities. The SPC project can be expected to generate significant long-term benefits such as greater internal security, healthier and safer communities, and responsible future citizens of a stable democracy.
==Vision== A humane and just society where citizens respect and follow laws willingly, practice responsible behavior towards others, demonstrate empathy for weaker sections of society, participate in tackling community issues and resist threats to the natural environment.
==Mission== To unlock the potential of youth by systematic training and make them capable of becoming social leaders with global vision guided by humanitarian values.
== Objectives == * To mould a generation of youth who willingly respect and abide by Law, and who practice civic sense, democratic behavior and selfless service to society as the natural way of life. * To facilitate development of good health, physical and mental fitness, self-control and discipline in youth, thereby enhancing their capacity for hard work and personal achievement. * To enable youth to work with police and other enforcement authorities including Forest, Transport, and Excise in preventing crime, maintaining law and order, promoting road safety, and improving internal security and disaster management. * To develop social commitment in youth and empower them against deviant behavior in themselves and others, thereby preventing growth of social evils such as drug and alcohol abuse, intolerance, vandalism, separatism, and terrorism in society. * To enable youth to explore and develop their inner potential in achieving success, by inculcating in them leadership, teamwork skills, innovative thinking and problem solving ability. * To increase knowledge and understanding of effective use of Information and Communications Technology (ICT) among youth, preventing its negative influence and enabling them to benefit from the vast potential of ICT. * To motivate youth to develop secular outlook, respect for other's fundamental rights and willingness to carry out their fundamental duties as enshrined in the Constitution of India by developing in them qualities of Patriotism, Open-mindedness, Large-heartedness, Inclusiveness, Capability and Effectiveness (POLICE)
The objectives of the Student Police Cadet project are synchronous with the goals of the National Youth Policy of India which seeks to involve youth in the noble work of nation-building.
== SPC training programme ==
SPC training consists of a two-year programme with a focus on developing health and physical fitness, instilling social values, exploring inner capability and inculcating community living skills within students. There are five components of the programme, viz. Physical (Outdoor) Training, Indoor Training (Study Classes), Field Visits, Practical Training Projects, and Camps.
===Community Projects===
Leadership capabilities of SPCs are strengthened through awareness classes and self-development workshops, and through community activities targeting issues such as road safety,<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-04-18/kochi/31361098_1_red-cards-violators-zebra-lines] "Student police cadets nab traffic violators", ''Times of India'' 18 April 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Kochi/article3359818.ece]''The Hindu'', 27 April 2012</ref> drug and substance abuse, environmental protection,<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Kochi/article3874163.ece] "Student Police Cadets to be roped in to help boot out waste", Anand Haridas, "The Hindu", 8 September 2012</ref> and aspects of law and crime. <ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/article3386517.ece] "Muneer asks Student Police Cadets to guard society from militant forces","The Hindu", 5 May 2012</ref>
==Executive Hierarchy==
SPC Project implementation machinery is made up of a three-tier structure of specially designated officials at State, District and School-levels. The highest ranking executive official of the project is the State Nodal Officer – SPC Project. [[P Vijayan]] IPS, a senior police officer of the 1999 Kerala cadre, is the first (and current) State Nodal Officer of the SPC Project.
In each District, a police officer of suitable rank appointed as District Nodal Officer. Wherever there are SPC schools, the local Police Inspector with jurisdiction is designated as Police Student Liaison Officer (PSLO), with field-level responsibility of project implementation in the school(s) falling in that jurisdiction. PSLO reports to DNO on project implementation on a regular basis.
== Project administration ==
Project administration is carried out by Committees at the State, District and School levels. The State-level Advisory Committee is the highest policy-making body in the SPC hierarchy, with authority to approve selection of schools, formulate guidelines for project implementation, issue directions to SPC programme officials, and ensure adherence to project guidelines by all stakeholders. The Committee consists of senior Government officials from the various associating Departments, and is chaired by the State Police Chief. There are also district-level Advisory Committees, and school-level Advisory Committee
== Achievements and laurels ==
* Resolution passed in '''41st All India Police Science Congress''' held at Dehradun 2011 recommended all states of India to adopt the SPC project * '''Dr Manmohan Singh''', the Prime Minister of India interacted with a team of SPCs at Kochi in September 2012, and was impressed by their attitude and demeanour<ref>"Student Police Cadets meet Manmohan" [http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article3895457.ece]"The Hindu", 14 September 2012,</ref> * '''Kerala Road Safety Authority''' (KRSA) selected the SPC Project to carry out a statewide road safety awareness project, and sanctioned an amount of Rs One Crore (Rupees Ten Million) for the purpose * '''Kerala Legal Services Authority (KELSA)''', a statutory body of the Kerala High Court, designated SPCs as community-level ambassadors to promote [[legal awareness]] among community members<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/article3008513.ece]''The Hindu'', 18 March 2012</ref> * The public sector '''Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd''' partnered with the SPC network to promote energy conservation within communities * The '''State Institute for Educational Management & Training, (SIEMAT)''', Kerala conducted a statewide assessment of the project and found strong correlations between the existence of SPC units in a school and positive changes experienced by the student community, their parents and other community members, as well as a decline in student-centric incidents of crime.<ref>Aparna Unni,[http://ibnlive.in.com/news/on-donning-khaki/295339-60-122.html] "On Donning Khaki", 28 September 2012</ref>
== Expansion of project ==
The recommendation by the All India Police Science Congress ([[Dehra Dun]], 2011) that all states implement the SPC project,<ref> NIKHILA P SUNIL [http://www.hindu.com/2011/06/16/stories/2011061654660300.htm] "Student Police scheme may find favour in other States", ''The Hindu'', 16 June 2011,</ref> led to a team of police officers from Rajasthan visiting Kerala to study the project.<ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/article3587505.ece]"Rajasthan police team visits school to study SPC", ''The Hindu'' 30 June 2012</ref> Subsequently, [[Government of Rajasthan]] decided to launch the project in selected schools as a pilot project.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-10-07/jaipur/34305781_1_programme-government-schools-traffic-rules]"'Student police cadet' programme to be launched in state", ''Times of India'', 7 January 2012</ref> Several other states in India have also expressed interest in rolling out the scheme. It has also been reported that a nationwide rollout of the SPC project is being considered at the level of the [[Union Home Ministry]].<ref>Anand Haridas,[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3207395.ece],"Student Police Cadet project to go National" ''The Hindu'' 24 March 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.keralacm.gov.in/index.php/component/content/article/1023]"Student Police to be considered for police recruitment", ''Official website of Chief Minister of Kerala'' 25 August 2012,</ref><ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/article2318066.ece] "Slew of new schemes under 'student police'",''The Hindu'' 3 August 2011,</ref><ref>[http://www.mathrubhumi.com/english/story.php?id=127580] "SPCs to be considered for police recruitment: Kerala CM",''Mathrubhumi'', 27 August 2012</ref> <ref>[http://www.thesundayindian.com/en/story/student-police-cadet-a-success-story/14/40748] T Satisan, "Student Police Cadet, a success story", ''The Sunday Indian''18-09-2012</ref> On July 21, 2018 [[Rajnath Singh]] Minister of Home Affairs of India, rolled out the SPC programme, under which high school students across the country will be taught to become much more responsible citizens. <ref>{{cite news |title=School children and the police join hands! Rajnath Singh launches 'Student Police Cadet' |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/education-today/news/story/rajnath-singh-launches-student-police-cadet-1293473-2018-07-23 |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=India Today |date=July 23, 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Rajnath Singh Starts "Student Police Cadet" Project In Gurugram |url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/rajnath-singh-starts-student-police-cadet-project-in-gurugram-1887378 |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=NDTV.com |publisher=NDTV |date=July 21, 2018}}</ref>
In the year 2012 [[Gujarat police]] also replicated this program in the state the project was initiated by Mr.Hasmukh Patel an Indian Police services officer of the rank of [[Inspector general]] it stated in 4 districts of Surat Police Range which are made up of districts of [[Surat]],[[Valsad]].Tapi and [[Dang District, India|Dang]]. Today this project is operation in all the districts of gujarat with total school participating in the project is numbered 1105.
in the year 2018 government of india launched this programme across india. The launch was done by Home Minister Mr.[[Rajnath Singh]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: The Secret Life of the Zoo

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=September 2018}} {{italic title}} '''''The Secret Life of the Zoo''''' is a British [[documentary]] programme produced by Blast Films on behalf of [[Channel 4]]. The series is filmed on location at [[Chester Zoo]] in the North West of England. Series 1 - 5 were narrated by [[Olivia Colman]]. In October 2018 it was confirmed that actress, [[Tamsin Greig]] would narrate the 6th series
==Overview==
This series gives viewers behind the scenes access to the zoo including the staff and animals. The Zoo Keepers are interviewed and usually narrate a large part of their animals story. Six series have aired between 2016 and 2018. The 6th series started airing in the UK on Channel 4 from 31st October 2018
==Episodes==
{| class="wikitable" | ! Series 1 !! First aired !! Description |- | Episode 1 || 2 February 2016 || [[Asian elephant|Asian Elephant]], Thi-Hi-Way gives birth to female calf, Nandita. The [[Red panda|Red Pandas]] have cubs and the [[Chimpanzee]]s are fighting for dominance |- | Episode 2 || 9 February 2016 || The keepers face the challenge of moving a family of five rare [[Sumatran tiger|Sumatran Tigers]] to a brand new enclosure. The [[Tarantula|Montserrat Tarantulas]] are set up on a date. [[Sun bear|Sun Bears]], Milli and Toni join the collection from [[Rare Species Conservation Centre|The Rare Species Conservation Center]] in Kent |- | Episode 3 || 16 February 2016 || [[Giraffe|Rothshchild Giraffe]], Orla gives birth to a male calf named Kidepo. The keepers attempt to breed from the critically endangered [[Leptodactylus fallax|Mountain Chicken Frogs]] |- | Episode 4 || 23 February 2016 || Florence the [[Zebra|Grevy's Zebra]] arrives from the [[West Midland Safari Park]] to meet resident stallion, Mac. The elephant house is hit by a potentially deadly virus |- | Episode 5 || 1 March 2016 || The [[Humboldt penguin|Humboldt Penguin]] chicks are introduced to the main pool. Two new [[False gharial|Sunda Gharial]] Crocodiles arrive from France but refuse to eat. Boris the [[Chimpanzee]] takes a wild [[Moorhen]] chick hostage and keepers try to work out why two [[Malaysian giant turtle|Bornean River Turtles]] are not breeding |- | Episode 6 || 8 March 2016 || Female [[Black rhinoceros|Black Rhino]], Kitani is introduced to potential mate, Magadi. A baby [[Sumatran orangutan|Sumatran Orangutan]] is born |}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Series 2 !! Date first aired !! Description |- | Episode 1 || 17 November 2016 || [[Zebra|Grevy's Zebras]], Florence and Nadine are about to give birth. Keepers and vets try to encourage the [[Asiatic lion|Asian Lions]] to breed and the [[Phacochoerus|Warthog]] piglets are causing trouble |- | Episode 2|| 24 November 2016 || Willie, a male [[Bornean orangutan|Bornean Orangutan]] is introduced to Chester's resident females in the hopes of producing a baby. Kendari the [[Babirusa|Babirusia]] gives birth and the [[Asian small-clawed otter|Small Clawed Otters]] have a big surprise for their keepers. |- | Episode 3 || 1 December 2016 || Illness strikes the [[Humboldt penguin|Humboldt Penguin]] chicks. The [[Radiated tortoise|Radiated Tortoises]] are joined by two new females from Sweden |- | Episode 4 || 8 December 2016 || Oana the [[Anoa]] gives birth to a calf. [[Sumatran tiger|Sumatran Tigers]], Topan and Jaya leave Chester Zoo for zoos in France and Wales. The [[Capybara]]s are also experiencing a baby boom |- | Episode 5 || 15 December 2016 || An emergency is declared when the zoo keepers discover four [[Sumatran orangutan|Sumatran Orangutans]] have escaped from their new enclosure. The [[Meerkat]]s are fighting for dominance and keepers are hoping for a baby Elephant |- | Episode 6 || 22 December 2016 || "Secret Life of the Zoo at Christmas" - A rare [[Malayan tapir|Malayan Tapir]] calf is born. The [[Sumatran orangutan|Sumatran Orangutans]] are given Christmas presents and vets give Bali the [[Reticulated python|Reticulated Python]] a health check |}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Series 3 !! Date first aired !! Description |- | Episode 1 || 28 February 2017 || Komala the [[Indian rhinoceros|Indian Rhino]] is moving to a zoo in [[Turkey]]. Pedro the [[Giant anteater|Giant Anteater]] is seriously ill and the Asian Mantis are introduced for breeding |- | Episode 2 || 7 March 2017 || Tula the [[Giraffe|Rothschild Giraffe]] gives birth to a male calf named Murchison. The [[Humboldt penguin|Humboldt Penguin]] chicks are introduced to the adult pool |- | Episode 3 || 14 March 2017 || Kinky Tail the [[Cheetah]] falls ill and is taken to the vets. The [[Chimpanzee|Chimpanzee's]] are joined by a new female from Germany |- | Episode 4 || 21 March 2017 || [[Asian elephant|Asian Elephant]] Sundara gives birth to a female calf. Keepers name her Indali but her half sister, Nandita is not impressed. The [[Bush dog|Bush Dogs]] have pups and keepers want the [[Dynastinae|Rhino Beetles]] to reproduce |- | Episode 5 || 28 March 2017 || Jenny the [[South American tapir|Brazilian Tapir]] is seriously ill. A new male [[Crested porcupine|Crested Porcupine]] arrives as a potential mate for female, Roxy. Keepers try to breed from [[Black rhinoceros|Black Rhinos]], Kifaru and Malindi but Kifaru's health could be a problem |- | Episode 6 || 4 April 2017 || Two female [[African wild dog|African Wild Dogs]] arrive from [[Port Lympne Wild Animal Park]] in Kent to join Chester's two males. Stomp and K'tusha the [[Okapi]]s are introduced for the first time and keepers try to entice romance between the [[Cassowary]] |- | Episode 7 || 11 April 2017 || [[Asian elephant|Asian Elephant]], Sithami gives birth to male calf, Aayu. Murchison the Giraffe calf will not go outside and a female [[Chameleon]] arrives from Paris |}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Series 4 !!Date first aired!! Description |- | Episode 1 || 15 November 2017 || Hazina, a rare [[Black rhinoceros|Black Rhino]] calf is born to mum, Kitani. The zoo receive four [[Lowland streaked tenrec|Lowland Streaked Tenrecs]] for a new breeding programme and attempts are made to breed the unusual [[Emerald cockroach wasp|Jewel Wasps]] |- | Episode 2 || 22 November 2017 || Jung the [[Red panda|Red Panda]] is losing weight and his keepers are unsure why. JC the [[Mandrill]] goes to the vets for a health check and Kasarna the [[Sumatran tiger|Sumatran Tiger]] is having to find her own dinner |- | Episode 3 || 29 November 2017 || Zoo keepers are delighted when [[Spectacled bear|Spectacled Bear]], Lima gives birth to the zoos first ever cub. However it is not long before little Madidi is getting into trouble. The Pygmy Marmosets have also had twins |- | Episode 4 || 6 December 2017 || Male [[Onager]], Holmes has been introduced to the females for breeding. The [[Chimpanzee]]s have a new toy but keeper, Niall needs it back |- | Episode 5 || 13 December 2017 || Two [[Black-and-white ruffed lemur|Belted Ruffed Lemurs]] join the bachelor [[Ring-tailed lemur|Ring Tailed Lemurs]] on their Island. Keepers pair up two [[Javan green magpie|Javan Green Magpies]] in the hope of saving the species |- | Episode 6 || 20 December 2017 || "Secret Life of the Zoo at Christmas" - Keepers prepare Christmas presents for the animals. A litter of [[Common dwarf mongoose|Dwarf Mongoose]] pups are born |- | Episode 7 || 2 January 2018 || The keepers try to encourage the [[Two-toed sloth|Two Toed Sloths]], Tina and Rico to breed with a new outdoor enclosure. Tripod the three legged [[Chameleon]] is paired up with a potential mate |- | Episode 8 || 9 January 2018 || The keepers have to move three [[Malayan tapir|Malayan Tapirs]] to a new enclosure. Roxy and Hendrix the [[Crested porcupine|Crested Porcupines]] have a baby and some new male [[Golden poison frog|Golden Dart Frogs]] arrive |- | Episode 9 || 16 January 2018 || Zuri the [[Black rhinoceros|Black Rhino]] gives birth to a male calf. The keepers name him Ike. [[Sun bear|Sun Bears]], Milli and Toni are moving to a new enclosure and Shan-Shan the [[Bactrian camel|Bactrian Camel]] is seriously ill |- | Episode 10 || 23 January 2018 || The keepers try to breed [[Big-belly seahorse|Big Bellied Seahorses]]. Himba the [[Aardvark]] moves to a zoo in Germany, and a male [[Philippine mouse-deer|Balabac Mouse Deer]] arrives as a potential mate for the zoos youngest female |}
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Series 5 !! Date first aired !! Description |- | Episode 1 || 18 April 2018 || A new pair of Meerkats arrive. Subis the Sumatran Orangutan gives birth but there are complications. Keepers try to breed from some rare [[Chameleon|Three Horned Chameleons]] |- | Episode 2 || 25 April 2018 || Stuma the [[Okapi]] falls ill. K'mana the [[African wild dog|African Wild Dog]] produces a litter of 7 puppies |- | Episode 3 || 2 May 2018 || Orla the [[Giraffe|Rothschild Giraffe]] gives birth to calf, Narus. A baby [[Bornean orangutan|Bornean Orangutan]] is born to mum, Sareki. Keepers try to breed from a young male [[Elephant shrew|Sengi]] and some [[Northern bald ibis|Northern Bald Ibis]] are let outside for the first time |- | Episode 4|| 9 May 2018 || Health checks are performed on the [[African wild dog|African Wild Dogs]] pups. Emma the [[Sumatran orangutan|Sumatran Orangutan]] gives birth to a new baby but concerns are raised about the health of her older baby, Tripa. |- | Episode 5 || 16 May 2018 || Two [[Spider monkey|Spider Monkeys]] are born. The keepers pair up [[Babirusa|Babirusias]], Sausu and Marjene for breeding |- | Episode 6 || 23 May 2018 || The keepers have to load Kidepo the [[Giraffe]] into a trailer for his journey to [[France]]. Dobby the [[Phacochoerus|Warthog]] is off to [[Germany]] and Garry the [[Dracaena (lizard)|Caiman Lizard]] is unlucky in love |}
{| class="wikitable" | ! Series 6 !! First aired !! Description |- | Episode 1 || 31 October 2018 || Asian Elephant, Thi is pregnant again but keepers are worried for mum and her unborn baby. A new male Giant Anteater arrives as a potential mate for female, Bliss and Meru the Giraffe is on a mission |- | Episode 2 || 6 November 2018|| |- | Episode 3 || TBC || |- | Episode 4 || TBC || |- | Episode 5 || TBC|| |- | Episode 6 || TBC || |}
==Awards==
The series was nominated for a BAFTA in the Television Features category. However it lost out to ''[[Cruising with Jane McDonald]]'' at the ceremony on 13 May 2018.
