revision.text:
'''Universal Design for Learning''' ('''UDL''') is an educational framework based on research in the learning sciences, including cognitive neuroscience, that guides the development of flexible learning environments that can accommodate individual learning differences.<ref>Rose, DH, & Meyer, A (2002) ''Teaching Every Student in the Digital Age: Universal Design for Learning'' Alexandria, VA: ASCD.</ref>
Recognizing that the way individuals learn can be unique, the UDL framework, first defined by David H. Rose, Ed.D. of the Harvard Graduate School of Education and the Center for Applied Special Technology (CAST) in the 1990s,<ref>Orkwis, R, & McLane, K (1998). A curriculum every student can use: Design principles for student access. ERIC/OSEP Topical Brief No. ED423654. Reston, VA: ERIC/OSEP Special Project.</ref> calls for creating curriculum from the outset that provides:
* ''Multiple means of representation'' to give learners various ways of acquiring information and knowledge, * ''Multiple means of expression'' to provide learners alternatives for demonstrating what they know, and * ''Multiple means of engagement'' to tap into learners' interests, challenge them appropriately, and motivate them to learn.<ref>Rose & Meyer, 2002, p. 75;</ref><ref>CAST (2008) Universal design for learning guidelines 1.0. Wakefield, MA: CAST. Retrieved July 1, 2008 from {{cite web |url=http://www.cast.org/publications/UDLguidelines/version1.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518032704/http://cast.org/publications/UDLguidelines/version1.html |archivedate=2008-05-18 |df= }}</ref>
Curriculum, as defined in the UDL literature, has four parts: instructional goals, methods, materials, and assessments.<ref name="Rose & Meyer, 2002">Rose & Meyer, 2002</ref> UDL is intended to increase access to learning by reducing physical, cognitive, intellectual, and organizational barriers to learning, as well as other obstacles. UDL principles also lend themselves to implementing inclusionary practices in the classroom.
Universal Design for Learning is referred to by name in American legislation, such as the Higher Education Opportunity Act (HEOA) of 2008 (Public Law 110-315),<ref>[http://www.udlcenter.org/advocacy/referencestoUDL/HEOA Legislative Overview, Universal Design for Learning Task Force ]</ref> the 2004 reauthorization of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Assistive Technology Act of 1998. The emphasis being placed on equal access to curriculum by all students and the accountability required by IDEA 2004 and No Child Left Behind legislation has presented a need for a practice that will accommodate all learners.<ref>Karger, J. (2005). What IDEA and NCLB suggest about curriculum access for students with disabilities. In DH Rose, A Meyer, & C Hitchcock, Eds. ''The Universally Designed Classroom: Accessible Curriculum and Digital Technologies.'' Cambridge, MA: Harvard Education Press.</ref>
==Origins== The concept and language of Universal Design for Learning was inspired by the [[universal design]] movement in architecture and product development, originally formulated by [[Ronald L. Mace]] at [[North Carolina State University]].<ref name="Rose & Meyer, 2002"/> Universal design calls for "the design of products and environments to be usable by all people, to the greatest extent possible, without the need for adaptation or specialized design".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.design.ncsu.edu/cud/about_ud/udprinciples.htm |title=Center for Universal Design, NCSU |access-date=2008-05-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513071023/http://www.design.ncsu.edu/cud/about_ud/udprinciples.htm |archive-date=2008-05-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> UDL applies this general idea to learning: that curriculum should, from the outset, be designed to accommodate all kinds of learners.<ref>Meyer & Rose, 2002</ref> Educators have to be deliberate in the teaching and learning process in the classroom (e.g Preparing class learning profiles for each student). This will enable grouping by interest. Those students that have challenges will be given special assistance. This will enable specific multimedia to meet the needs of all students. However, recognizing that the UD principles created to guide the design of things (e.g., buildings, products) are not adequate for the design of social interactions (e.g., human learning environments), researchers at CAST looked to the neurosciences and theories of progressive education in developing the UDL principles.<ref>Rose & Meyer, 2002; CAST, 2008</ref> In particular, the work of [[Lev Vygotsky]] and, less directly, [[Benjamin Bloom]] informed the three-part UDL framework.<ref>CAST, 2008</ref>
Some educational initiatives, such as [[Universal design for instruction|Universal Design for Instruction]] (UDI) and [[Universal Instructional Design]] (UID), adapt the Mace principles for products and environments to learning environments, primarily at the postsecondary level. While these initiatives are similar to UDL and have, in some cases, compatible goals, they are not equivalent to UDL and the terms are not interchangeable; they refer to distinct frameworks.<ref>McGuire, JM, Scott, SS, & Shaw, SF (2006). Universal design and its applications in educational environments. ''Remedial and Special Education 27''(3), 166-175</ref> On the other hand, UDI practices promoted by the [[The DO-IT Center|DO-IT Center]] operationalize both UD and UDL principles to help educators maximize the learning of all students.<ref>Burgstahler, S., "Equal Access: Universal Design of Instruction", 2011, "[http://www.washington.edu/doit/Brochures/Academics/equal_access_udi.html]"</ref>
==Implementation initiatives in the US== In 2006, representatives from more than two dozen educational and disability organizations in the US formed the National Universal Design for Learning Taskforce. The goal was to raise awareness of UDL among national, state, and local policymakers.<ref>National Taskforce on UDL, www.udl4allstudents.org</ref>
The organizations represented in the National Task Force on UDL include the National School Boards Association, the National Education Association (NEA), the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), the National Association of State Directors of Special Education (NASDSE), the Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO), the National Down Syndrome Society (NDSS), the Council for Learning Disabilities (CLD),the Council for Exceptional Children (CEC), the National Center for Learning Disabilities (NCLD), the National Association of Secondary School Principals (NASSP), Easter Seals, American Foundation for the Blind (AFB), Association on Higher Education and Disability, Higher Education Consortium for Special Education (HECSE), American Occupational Therapy Association, National Association of State Boards of Education (NASBE), National Down Syndrome Congress (NDSC), Learning Disabilities Association of America (LDA), TASH, the Arc of the United States, the Vocational Evaluation and Career Assessment Professionals Association (VECAP), the National Cerebral Palsy Association, and the Advocacy Institute.<ref>National Task Force on UDL, www.udl4allstudents.org</ref>
Activities have included sponsoring a Congressional staff briefing on UDL in February 2007 and supporting efforts to include UDL in major education legislation for both K-12 and postsecondary.
==Research== Despite the popularity of UDL among educators and disability support professionals, little research has been conducted to evaluate its effectiveness as a model of good pedagogy.
UDL can be used in the support of students with disabilities and as well as learning differences. In actual case studies conducted by Elizabeth McAra-Craford (Araford Education 2015, Halifax, Nova Scotia), applying Universal Design principles expands the ability of students to access needed supports in post-secondary settings.
==Related publications== A number of books and journal articles have been published on the subject of Universal Design for Learning. These include:
* ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=FDhxex8_UqIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Universal+Design+for+Learning+in+the+Classroom&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UK4eUbyqF8K8igKhrIGIAQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Universal%20Design%20for%20Learning%20in%20the%20Classroom&f=false Universal Design for Learning in the Classroom: Practical Applications]'', edited by Tracey E. Hall, Anne Meyer, and David H. Rose. Guilford Press, 2012. {{ISBN|978-1-4625-0635-4}}. *''Learning to Read in the Digital Age'' (1998) by Anne Meyer and David H. Rose. Cambridge, MA: Brookline Books. *''Teaching Every Student in the Digital Age: Universal Design for Learning'' (2002) by David H. Rose & Anne Meyer, with Nicole Strangman and Gabrielle Rappolt. Alexandria, VA: Association of Supervision & Curriculum Development; *''The Universally Designed Classroom: Accessible Curriculum and Digital Technologies'' (2005), edited by David H. Rose, Anne Meyer, and Chuck Hitchcock. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Education Press. *''A Practical Reader in Universal Design for Learning'' (2006), edited by David H. Rose and Anne Meyer. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Education Press. *Burgstahler, Sheryl, & Cory, Rebecca. (2008). ''Universal Design in Higher Education: From Principles to Practice.'' Cambridge, MA: Harvard Education Press. *Schelly, Catherine L., Davies, Patricia L., & Spooner, Craig L. (2011). Student Perceptions of Faculty Implementation of Universal Design for Learning. ''Journal of Postsecondary Education and Disability, 24''(1), 17-28. *''Your UDL Lesson Planner: The Step-by-Step Guide for Teaching all Learners'' (2016), by Patti Kelly Ralabate. Brookes Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1681250021}} *''Culturally Responsive Design for English Learners: The UDL Approach'' (2017), by Patti Kelly Ralabate and Loui Lord Nelson. CAST Professional Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1930583054}}
==Summary== Universal Design for Learning is a promising, research-based framework approach for improving the quality of education across grade levels and subjects for all learners.
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.cast.org/research/udl/index.html What is Universal Design for Learning?] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140314045016/http://www.udl4allstudents.org/ National Universal Design for Learning Task Force] *[https://archive.is/20130414164346/http://www.cast.org/tes/ Teaching Every Student in the Digital Age: Universal Design for Learning] *[http://www.uvm.edu/cdci/universaldesign/ UDL@UVM (Universal Design for Learning at the University of Vermont)] *[http://accessproject.colostate.edu/udl/ UDL Technical Modules (Tips and techniques for creating universally designed Word, HTML and PDF documents)] *[http://www.washington.edu/doit/CUDE/ Center for Universal Design in Education] *[http://www.hoysiaprendo.com/ e-learning Center Hoy Si Aprendo]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Universal Design For Learning}} [[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Higher education]]

page.title: University Without Walls (University of Massachusetts Amherst)

revision.text:
{{Infobox academic division | name = University Without Walls | image_name = File:UMASS_UWW_LOGO.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | motto = | motto_lang = | motto_eng = | established = {{Start date|1971}} | closed = | type = | parent = [[University of Massachusetts]] | city = [[Amherst, Massachusetts|Amherst]] | state = [[Massachusetts]] | country = [[United States of America]] | coor = | director = Ingrid Bracey, Ed.D. | academic_staff = 12 | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | website = {{URL|www.umass.edu/uww}} | logo = }}
'''University Without Walls, UMass Amherst''' (UWW) is a department at the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]] (UMass) which provides [[degree completion program|degree completion coursework]], primarily for [[non-traditional students]]. Established in 1971, as of 2013 approximately five-percent of UMass graduates were receiving their undergraduate degrees through the program annually.
==History== The University of Massachusetts' University Without Walls was one of a number of similar programs founded at 17 American universities in 1971 with the help of a grant from the United States [[Office of Education]] (other participating institutions included the [[University of Minnesota]], the [[University of South Carolina]], and [[Howard University]]). [[Samuel Baskin]] was considered the "driving force" behind the nationwide initiative.<ref>{{cite news |first=Hechinger |last=Fred |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Education Without Walls |url= |work=New York Times |publisher= |date=28 December 1970 }}</ref>
In 2010, Mark Cerasuolo became the first University of Massachusetts graduate from the University Without Walls program to deliver the University of Massachusetts' student commencement address.<ref>[http://www.umass.edu/uww/how-it-works/course-delivery UWW website]</ref>
As of 2013, an average of 250 students were annually receiving bachelor's degrees through the UMass University Without Walls program,<ref>{{cite news |last=Taras |first=Elizabeth |date=28 January 2014 |title=Opening Doors |url=http://businesswest.com/blog/opening-doors/ |newspaper=Business West |location= |publisher= |accessdate=30 January 2014 }}</ref> out of approximately 5,000 total undergraduate degrees annually awarded by the University of Massachusetts. Between 1971 and 2015, the University of Massachusetts had awarded approximately 3,000 degrees to students through the UWW program.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roman|first1=Elizabeth|title=UMass 'University Without Walls' offers informational session in Springfield|url=http://www.masslive.com/news/index.ssf/2015/08/umass_university_without_walls.html|accessdate=24 December 2015|work=The Republican (Springfield, Massachusetts)|date=24 August 2015}}</ref> The program enrolls more students who are veterans of the [[U.S. armed forces]] than any other academic department at the University of Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.umass.edu/uww/welcome-military-families |title=Welcome Military Families |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=umass.edu/uww |publisher=University of Massachusetts |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
==Structure== The UMass University Without Walls program only admits students who have already completed a minimum number of undergraduate university credits at the University of Massachusetts, or at another accredited institution, and have a minimum cumulative [[grade point average]] in those credits.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schramm|first1=Michael|title=Parents benefit from specialized degree program at UMass Amherst|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2015/06/09/umass-amherst-parent-degree-program/|accessdate=24 December 2015|work=[[USA Today]]|date=9 June 2015}}</ref> Once enrolled, students are required to take four program-specific courses, plus additional classes equal to the difference between their accumulated university credits and the University of Massachusetts' 120-credit graduation requirement. Program-specific courses are taught by dedicated UMass University Without Walls faculty and deal with academic writing, critical thinking, research skills, and issues analysis. Students who require additional courses to meet the 120-credit requirement make up the deficit through standard University of Massachusetts classes taken from the school's other academic departments.
Because the University Without Walls program functions as a regular academic department within the University of Massachusetts, students do not undertake an [[academic major]] (baccalaureate degrees are awarded in "University Without Walls"). Instead, nine interdisciplinary areas of study are offered - including applied psychology, arts administration, and journalism - each consisting of courses from several academic fields drawn from both the student's previously completed credits as well as University of Massachusetts courses he or she completes while enrolled in the program.
===Social justice residency=== Beginning in 2012, the UWW program began offering a "social justice residency," a one-credit, three-day, intensive course held at the University of Massachusetts' Springfield Center that teaches the "theory and practice of social justice activism, particularly as related to racial and economic inequality."<ref>{{cite news|title=UWW Hosts 3rd Annual Social Justice Residency|url=https://www.umass.edu/uww/node/2067|accessdate=24 December 2015|publisher=[[University of Massachusetts]]|date=29 September 2015}}</ref>
==People== ===Alumni=== * [[Nubar Alexanian]] - documentary photographer<ref name="Republican" /> * [[Julius Erving]] - NBA player<ref name="Republican" /> * [[Clare Higgins (politician)|Clare Higgins]] - [[mayor]] of [[Northampton, Massachusetts]]<ref name="Republican" /> * Thomas Merrigan - [[Franklin County, Massachusetts]] commissioner * [[Lou Roe]] - [[NBA]] player <ref>Former Minuteman Lou Roe excited to join Derek Kellogg's staff at UMass, Daily Hampshire Gazette, August 22, 2012 [http://www.gazettenet.com/2012/08/22/former-minuteman-lou-roe-will-return-to-umass-to-assist-derek-kellogg]</ref> * [[Jeff Taylor (entrepreneur)|Jeff Taylor]] - founder of [[monster.com]]<ref name="Republican">THUMBS UP, THUMBS DOWN - Breaking Down Walls, The Republican, Monday, June 25, 2007 [http://www.umass.edu/uww/news_events/news.html]</ref> * [[Steve Turre]] - Jazz Trombonist * [[Serena Williams]] - professional [[tennis]] player (student) * [[Marcus Camby]] - NBA player
===Faculty=== * [[Lawrence Hott]] * [[Lisa Aronson Fontes]] * [[Robert S. Welch]]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
{{University of Massachusetts Amherst}}
[[Category:University of Massachusetts Amherst]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Continuing education]]

A '''university counseling center''' ('''UCC''') provides [[mental health]] and other services within a [[university]] or college environment. The need for these services is on the rise. Counseling center directors and other student affairs personnel have reported an increase in the mental health needs of college students, with issues like [[Eating disorder|eating disorders]], [[Substance abuse|alcohol and drug abuse/dependence]], severe [[Mood disorder|depression]]/[[Anxiety disorder|anxiety]], [[Suicidal ideation|suicidality]], and [[sexual assault]] becoming more prevalent in this environment.<ref>Kitzrow, M. A. (2003). The mental health needs of today’s college students: Challenges and recommendations. The National Association of Student Personnel Administrators Journal, 41, 167-181.</ref> Among [[Big Ten Conference]] universities, directors report a 42% increase in the number of students seen at their counseling centers.<ref>Voelker, R. (2003). Mounting student depression taxing campus mental health services. Journal of the American Medical Association, 289, 2055-2056.</ref> In a summary of recent survey data, Duenwald also reports that the use of [[psychiatric medication]] has increased almost 10% among college students since the year 2000.<ref name="Times">{{cite news|last=Duenwald|first= M. |date=October 2004|title=The dorms may be great, but how's the counseling?|work= [[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/26/health/psychology/26cons.html}}</ref> May (2003) finds that a UCC will typically work with 15-20% of students at colleges and 8-12% at a university.<ref name="May">May, R. (2003). How much is enough?: Reflections on the Report of the Harvard provost's committee on student mental health services. Journal of College Student Psychotherapy, 17, 3-10.</ref> Given these numbers, May recommends 1 counselor per 600 students in colleges and a 1:1000 ratio in universities with an average of 5 to 6 sessions per student.<ref name="May"/>
UCCs generally offer a variety of services including individual and group [[counseling]], psychodiagnostic testing, alcohol and other drug counseling/evaluation, crisis assistance, campus outreach programs, consultation services, and graduate student training. Though services primarily target mental health problems (i.e., anxiety, depression), students also utilize counseling services to enhance areas of their life, including relationships, career/vocational choices, academic and athletic performance, and exploring psychological strengths. [[Lehigh University]] Counseling and Psychological Services (UCPS) is an example of a university counseling center.
Another example of a university counseling center is the [[University of California, Irvine]] Counseling Center. In addition to the services mentioned above, the center also offers Peer Programs. Peer Programs offered by the UCI Counseling Center include C.O.A.C.H, The Peer Educator Program, and the LGBTQ Mentorship Program. In these programs, students receive services not from licensed health professionals, but from other students at UCI who have assumed these helping roles. This is a different approach to counseling for students who find more comfort in speaking with fellow peers who they can more easily relate with. Each program has a different focus, whether it be group-based, individual-based, or special needs-based; but all have the same goal—to promote student mental health and well-being in all aspects of life.
== History ==
Early to mid 1940's: University counseling centers began formal operations, responding to the increasing educational and vocational needs of returning [[Veteran|veterans]] of [[World War II]].<ref name="AUCCCD">{{cite web|website=www.aucccd.org|year= 2005|title= About AUCCCD|url=http://www.aucccd.org/about-aucccd-new}}</ref>
1950: The Association of College Counseling Center Directors (AUCCCD) was established in 1950 by a group of mid-western college and university counseling directors. Dr. Ralph Birdie, director of the Student Counseling Bureau at the [[University of Minnesota, Minneapolis]] hosted the first conference on the UM campus. Annual meetings were hosted throughout the 1950s by several universities including the [[University of Illinois system|University of Illinois]], [[Michigan State University|Michigan State]], [[Ohio State University|The Ohio State University]], [[University of Iowa|State University of Iowa]], [[University of Missouri]], and the [[University of Minnesota]]. In the early days, the organization was referred to as the Annual Conference of College and University Counseling Directors. Conference attendance was based on invitation from participants and grew over time as directors around the country developed collegial relationships with each other. Initially membership was primarily drawn from mid-western institutions, but eventually the annual conference became a national affiliation of directors.
Following World War II, counseling centers were established in response to the educational and vocational needs of returning veterans. Directors were pioneering the development of organized counseling units and recognized their need to "talk shop" - to exchange information with each other and to develop a practical knowledge base on how to best to serve students. They gathered to discuss organizational issues, to share experience about how to work effectively with campus administration, and to discuss the nature of the work with students. An integral part of the annual meeting was the opportunity to develop and nourish collegial friendships through work and recreation in a restful setting.
Directors valued the opportunity to discuss confidential matters with their colleagues and trusted one another with sensitive details that they could not process with fellow administrators on their own campus. Directors were challenged with issues such as managing relations with campus administration and faculty who could be skeptical of the value of counseling students as well as issues related to the management of their staff. Conference attendance was restricted to directors with staffs of at least three [[Full-time equivalent|full-time equivalents]] (FTE) in order to create a confidential environment for consultation.
The annual conference provided the opportunity for both formal and ad hoc presentations, roundtable discussions, and individual consultation. The group was loosely organized as a "non-organization" with a minimum of bureaucracy, and the pivotal activity was the annual meeting. A steering committee was elected annually to manage routine business, and a conference host was chosen from among competing institutions during the conference business meeting.
The formal structure of AUCCCD as we now know it developed slowly through the 1980s with the decision to revise the organization's By-laws and to incorporate as a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organization]]. Throughout the 1990s several initiatives have been undertaken to develop a formal organizational structure to advance the business of AUCCCD as a national [[Professional association|professional organization]], and to put significant emphasis on advocating on behalf of counseling and psychological issues in higher education. Conference membership increased considerably after the 3 FTE restriction was lifted in the 1990s.
Membership in AUCCCD is institutional, with one director being selected to represent the member college or university. The group has experienced significant growth, with a current membership of 836 universities and colleges throughout the [[United States]], [[Canada]], and [[Europe]] and [[Asia]].<ref name="AUCCCD"/>
1960s: As outpatient psychiatric clinics and services became more accessible to the general public, university counseling centers also began to provide standard psychological services to college students, including individual, couples, and group [[psychotherapy]]; vocational and personality assessment; consultative services to college administration, faculty, parents, and students; and [[crisis management]] among other services to the campus community.<ref>{{cite web|work=The George Washington University Counseling Center|year=2008|title= History of the UCC|url=http://gwired.gwu.edu/counsel/AboutTheUCC/HistoryOfUCC}}</ref>
1968: The Association of Psychology Postdoctoral and Internship Centers (APPIC) began formally coordinating pre-doctoral and post doctoral [[Internship|internships]] and jobs. Currently, there are 444 pre-doctoral internships listed through APPIC.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appic.org/|title=APPIC - Association of Psychology Postdoctoral and Internship Centers|website=www.appic.org}}</ref>
1978: The Association of Counseling Center Training Agencies (ACCTA) was established to coordinate the training objectives of university counseling centers, including creation and maintenance of pre-doctoral internship and [[practicum]] programs.<ref>Heppner, P. P., Casas, J. M., Carter, J., & Stone, G. L. (2000). The maturation of counseling psychology: Multifaceted perspectives, 1978-1998. In S. D. Brown & R. W. Lent (Eds.), ''Handbook of counseling psychology (3rd ed.)''. New York: Wiley.</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://ccvillage.buffalo.edu Counseling Center Village] Website created by and for university & college counseling center professionals. * [http://www.myacpa.org/commcaps/ Commission for Counseling and Psychological Services (CCAPS)] ACPA's counseling center commission. * [http://www.aucccd.org Association for University and College Counseling Center Directors].
[[Category:School counseling]]

The '''University of Timbuktu''' is a collective term for the teaching associated with three mosques in the city of [[Timbuktu]] in what is now [[Mali]]: the masajid ([[mosque]]s) of [[Sankore Madrasah|Sankore]], [[Djinguereber]], and [[Sidi Yahya Mosque|Sidi Yahya]].{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wonders/Episodes/Epi5/5_wondr6.htm |title=Wonders: Sankore Mosque |publisher=[[PBS]]}} It was not a [[university]] in the modern sense, but a loosely organized scholastic community that endured for many centuries during the medieval period. {{TOC right}} ==History== Timbuktu quickly grew in importance by the start of the 12th century, with a thriving economy based on trading salt, gold, spices and dyes. As the wealth of the city grew, it also became a center of learning, attracting scholars and manuscripts.{{cite web |url=http://www.livescience.com/26451-timbuktu.html |title=Timbuktu: History of Fabled Center of Learning |author=Owen Jarus |publisher=[[Live Science]]}} It acquired a reputation for learning and scholarship across the Muslim world. According to African scholar Shamil Jeppie in ''The Meanings of Timbuktu'':
...Timbuktu is a repository of history, a living archive which anybody with a concern for African history should be acquainted with. Timbuktu may be hard to get to but it played an essential role as a centre of scholarship under the [[Songhai Empire|Songhay state]] until the invasion from the rulers of Marrakesh in 1591, and even thereafter it was revived.Shamil Jeppie & Souleymane Bachir Diagne (eds). ''The Meanings of Timbuktu''. HSRC Pess: Cape Town, 2008
After Timbuktu was occupied because of the 1591 [[Battle of Tondibi]], the university went into decline. In 1593, [[Ahmad al-Mansur|Ahmad I al-Mansur]] cited "disloyalty" as the reason for arresting, and subsequently killing or exiling, many of Timbuktu's scholars, including [[Ahmad Baba al Massufi]].{{cite book | last=Hunwick | first= John O.| year=2003 |title= Timbuktu and the Songhay Empire: Al-Sadi's Tarikh al-Sudan down to 1613 and other contemporary documents | publisher=Brill| place=Leiden | |pages=lxii–lxiii | isbn=90-04-12560-4}} ==The university== The University of Timbuktu was unlike the modern [[university]] in that there was no central organization or formal course of study. Instead, there were several independent schools, each having its own principal instructor. Students chose their teachers, and instruction took place in mosque courtyards or private residences. The primary focus was on study of the [[Quran]] and Islamic subjects, but academic subjects were also taught, such as "medicine and surgery, astronomy, mathematics, physics, chemistry, philosophy, language and linguistics, geography, history, as well as art."{{cite web |url=http://www.muslimheritage.com/article/university-sankore-timbuktu |title=The University of Sankore, Timbuktu |publisher=Foundation for Science, Technology and Civilisation}} Teachers associated with the Sankore mosque and the mosque itself were especially respected for learning. It boasted up to 25,000 students out of a total city population of 100,000.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/119 |title=Timbuktu |publisher=[[UNESCO]]}} Noted scholars associated with the institution include: * [[Mohammed Bagayogo]] (1523-1593), associated with the Sankore masajid * [[Ahmad Baba al Massufi]] (1556-1627), a student of Mohammed Bagayogo and the author of more than 40 books; deported to Morocco in 1594 ==Manuscripts== {{Main|Timbuktu Manuscripts}} Of the tens or hundreds of thousands of manuscripts written or copied in Timbuktu, some were taken by the French, the former colonial masters, but many surviving examples had been stored in the Ahmed Baba Institute of Higher Islamic Studies and Research, Timbuktu's main library, which was completed in 2009.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/28/timbuktu-library-centuries-african-history |title=Timbuktu library – a treasure house of centuries of Malian history |date=28 January 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} However, [[al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] (AQIM), a terrorist group, took control of the city{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/28/mali-timbuktu-library-ancient-manuscripts |title=Timbuktu mayor: Mali rebels torched library of historic manuscripts |date=28 January 2013 |newspaper=The Guardian}} in 2012. They were forced out by French and Malian government troops the next year, but not before setting fire to two buildings housing many of the manuscripts, including the Ahmed Baba Institute. Most of the manuscripts had been removed and hidden before the AQIM takeover.{{cite web|last=Walt |first=Vivienne |url=http://world.time.com/2013/01/28/mali-timbuktu-locals-saved-some-of-their-citys-ancient-manuscripts-from-islamists/ |title=Mali: Timbuktu’s Ancient Manuscripts Are Safe, Preservationists Say | TIME.com |publisher=World.time.com |date=28 January 2013}} ==External links== * [http://international.loc.gov/intldl/malihtml/malihome.html Islamic Manuscripts from Mali] - ''U.S. Library of Congress'' ==References== {{Reflist}} {{University of Timbuktu}} [[Category:History of Mali]] [[Category:History of Azawad]] [[Category:Mali Empire]] [[Category:Songhai Empire]] [[Category:Ancient universities]] [[Category:Universities in Mali]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in the 10th century]]

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Victor Mosele''' was a [[Catholic]] [[Xaverian Brothers|Xaverian]] [[missionary]] [[priest]]. He spent 30 years in [[Sierra Leone]] building [[schools]], [[clinics]], and promoting his [[religion]]. At one point, he was in charge of 33 different schools, including 6,000 children.
According to a Xaverian Missionary Newsletter of 1999, Mosele was captured by the rebel army in [[Kambia (Sierra Leone)|Kambia]] near [[Guinea]] on February 11, 1999. He had turned back in an effort to acquire medicine for the wounded when he was met by the [[Revolutionary United Front|RUF]] rebels and taken to [[Makeni]].
On September 6 he was captured again along with Fr. [[Franco Manganello]] at [[Pamelap]] near the border of [[Guinea]]. In one of Mosele's accounts of his experiences in Sierra Leone, he recalls that the people who captured him had been part of the schools he established. On October 4, 2000 [[Pope John Paul II]] made an appeal at his general audience to the rebel army for peace and for the release of Victor Mosele and Franco Manganello.
==From 2009== Mosele was at the campus ministry center, [http://www.uwcatholic.org] in [[Madison, WI]], and was then stationed at [[Illinois State University]]'s [http://www.isucatholic.org St. Robert Bellarmine Catholic Center] during the 2009-10 school year. He wrote a book about his experiences titled '''Running For My Life''', which was published in Fall 2006. He died on August 23, 2012 and was buried on August 28, 2012.
==External links== *[http://www.xaviermissionaries.org/M_Life/NewsArchive/AmericaNews/US_PriestStory.htm Story of Survival] *[http://www.xaviermissionaries.org/M_Life/NewsArchive/AmericaNews/US_MoseleCampus.htm Campus Ministry] *{{cite web|url=http://hypertextbook.com/eworld/magburaka.shtml|title=Rebel Forces Attack Magburaka|work=E-World -- Sierra Leone, et al.|first=James|last=Tully|year=1998}} *[http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/audiences/2000/documents/hf_jp-ii_aud_20001004_en.html Pope John Paul II General Audience Wednesday October 4, 2000] *[http://www.onlinehomilies.com/cachedrecordings/recording-1046-8.mp3 Homily and Personal Account of Victor Mosele regarding Sierra Leone] *[http://www.sierra-leone.org/slnews1000.html Sierra Leone News Archives] * [https://www.theobooks.org/index.asp?PageAction=VIEWPROD&ProdID=1340 '''Running For My Life''' -- Fr. Victor Mosele's book]
{{authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Wilhelmina Weber Furlong | image = Weber-Furlong-1898.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Weber Furlong 1898 in Paris | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1878|11|24}} | birth_place = [[St.Louis]], [[Missouri]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1962|05|25|1878|11|24}} | death_place = [[Glens Falls, New York]] | nationality = [[German–American]] | field = Painting | training = [[Art Students League]] | movement = [[Modern art]], [[abstract art]], [[Fauvism]], [[impressionism]], [[post-impressionism]], [[expressionism]], [[cubism]] | works = | patrons = [[Gertrude Stein]], [[Claribel Cone|Etta Cone]], [[Claribel Cone]], [[Oliver Gould Jennings]], [[Hyde Collection|Hyde Collection Museum]], [[Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery|Tang Museum]], [[Bolton Museum]], [[Weber Furlong Foundation]], [[Building 98|Studio 98]], [[Skidmore College]] | spouse = Thomas Furlong | website = {{URL| 1=www.weberfurlong.com }} | influenced by = [[Paul Cézanne]], [[Henri Matisse]], [[Emil Carlsen]], [[William Merritt Chase]], [[Edmund H. Wuerpel]], [[Pablo Picasso]] | influenced = [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]], [[Jackson Pollock]], [[Willem de Kooning]], [[Edward Hopper]], [[Dorothy Dehner]], [[Jean Charlot|Jean Charolot]], [[Alexander Calder]], [[Rockwell Kent]], [[Max Weber (artist)|Max Weber]], [[Allen Tucker]], [[John D. Graham|John Graham]], [[Thomas Hart Benton (painter)|Thomas Hart Benton]], [[Kimon Nicolaïdes]], [[Thomas (Tomas) Furlong]] | awards = }}
'''Wilhelmina Weber Furlong''' (1878–1962) was a [[German American]] artist and teacher.<ref name="TheBiography">The Biography of Wilhelmina Weber Furlong: The Treasured Collection of Golden Heart Farm by Clint B. Weber, {{ISBN|978-0-9851601-0-4}}</ref>
Among America's earliest [[avant-garde]] elite modernist painters, Weber Furlong was a major American artist who pioneered modern [[impressionistic]] and modern [[expressionistic]] [[still life]] painting at the turn of the [[List of 20th-century women artists|twentieth century's American]] [[American modernism|modernist movement]].<ref name="ProfessorEmeritus">Professor Emeritus James K. Kettlewell: Harvard, Skidmore College, Curator The Hyde Collection. Foreword to The Treasured Collection of Golden Heart Farm: {{ISBN|978-0-9851601-0-4}}</ref>
She has been called<ref name="TheBiography"/><ref name="ProfessorEmeritus"/> the first female [[American modernism|modernist painter]] in the early American Modernism scene, and she represents the struggles of many [[List of 20th-century women artists|women artists]] in the late 1800s and early 1900s as they became subjugated to the many [[Realism (arts)|realists]]<ref name="TheBiography"/><ref name="ProfessorEmeritus"/> who opposed the [[American modernism|American modernist movement]] and serious [[women artists]].<ref name="WEBpressum">{{Cite book|asin=0985160101|publisher=The Weber Furlong Press, New York|title=America's First Female Modern Artists Local The Biography & Catalogue, August 7, 2012 |work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film & Biography}}</ref><ref name="WEBpressum2">{{Cite book|asin=098516011X|publisher=The Weber Furlong Press, New York|title=Weber Furlong Retrospective Catalogue The Biography & Catalogue, June 7, 2013 |work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Exhibition}}</ref><ref name="WEBpressum3">{{cite web|url=http://www.weberfurlong.com/About.html|publisher=The Weber Furlong Collection, New York|title=About Weber Furlong Weber Furlong website 2014|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Foundation}}</ref>
==Biography== Beginning in 1892 her teachers included [[Emil Carlsen]], [[William Merritt Chase]], and [[Edmund H. Wuerpel]].<ref name="TheBiography" /> She was present at the [[Salon d'Automne]] or [[Autumn Salon]] for three years and she knew [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Paul Cézanne]], and others who exhibited at the [[Paris Salon]]. In the [[American modernism]] movement she painted between 1892 and 1962 where she thrived during the modernist movement in [[St. Louis]], New York City, and Paris from 1897 to 1906. She painted in [[Mexico City]] from 1906 to 1913 and again in New York City from 1913 to 1947. She was also active during the formative years of the modernist movement in New York City and the popular 1913 Manhattan studio gallery of Wilhelmina Weber Furlong was highlighted in her biography. She also painted in [[Bolton Landing]], [[New York State|New York]] from 1921 to 1960 at her Modern [[art colony]], [[Golden Heart Farm]]<ref name="TheBiography" /> and simultaneously in [[Glens Falls]], New York<ref>The Hyde Collection Museum Glens Falls, New York on Permanent display</ref> from 1952 to 1962.<ref name="poststarsum">{{cite web|url=http://poststar.com/news/local/artist-honored-glens-falls-painter-was-at-forefront-of-modern/article_ae3c9e68-eb70-11e2-9bbd-0019bb2963f4.html|publisher=Post Star Glens Falls, New York|title=Artist Honored in Glens Falls, Woman Painter Was at Forefront of Modern Change July 12, 2013|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong New York State Historic Marker and Documentary Film}}</ref>
In America her significant circle of friends and acquaintances includes [[John D. Graham|John Graham]],<ref name="SmithsonianArchives">Smithsonian Archives of American Art Oral history interviews with Dorothy Dehner, 1965 Oct.-1966</ref> [[Willem de Kooning]], [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]],<ref name="SmithsonianArchives" /> [[Dorothy Dehner]],<ref name="SmithsonianArchives" /> [[Jean Charlot]], [[Edward Hopper]], [[Alexander Calder]], [[Rockwell Kent|Rockwell and Sally Kent]], [[Thomas Hart Benton (painter)|Thomas Hart Benton]], [[Allen Tucker]], [[Max Weber (artist)|Max Weber]], [[Kimon Nicolaïdes|Kimon Nicolaidies]], and many others. As a student, she was associated with the [[Art Students League]] as a young woman prior to 1900 and in 1913 began a serious role in the New York art scene at the Art Students League as a Secretary Treasurer and member of the Board of Control along with her husband, the artist [[Thomas (Tomas) Furlong|Thomas Furlong]].<ref name="TheBiography" /><ref name="pressrepsum">{{cite web|url=http://pressrepublican.com/0500_what_to_do/x1472219606/Biographer-seeking-local-info-on-artist|publisher=Press Republican Plattsburgh, New York|title=Biographer Seeking Local Information on Artist June 27, 2013|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary}}</ref> She taught art for over 56 years in New York<ref name="TheBiography" /> and she was active with the [[Whitney Museum of American Art|Whitney Studio Club]] during the formative years of the organization in New York City a fact revealed in the Studio Club archives.<ref>The Whitney Museum Library archival items number 15405</ref><ref>Smithsonian Archives of American Art Detailed description of the Ben Benn papers, 1905–1993</ref>
==Legacy and honors==
Weber Furlongs' close association in Bolton Landing, New York with the sculptor David Smith has had a lasting influence on the hamlet to this very day and she is known to be responsible for bringing him to the farm he purchased there with his wife sculptor and painter Dorothy Dehner. Weber Furlong's works are on permanent display at the Bolton Landing Museum.<ref name="SmithsonianArchives"/><ref>[http://boltonhistorical.org/museum/museum.html Historical Society Museum of Bolton Landing, New York]</ref><ref name="mirrorsum">{{cite web|url=http://www.lakegeorgemirrormagazine.com/tag/bolton-artist/|publisher=Lake George Mirror|title=Documenting the Life and Times of Bolton Artist Weber Furlong July 24, 2012|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary}}</ref>
[[The Hyde Collection]] in Glens Falls, New York has displayed the works of Wilhelmina Weber Furlong since 1966 where they hosted a major solo retrospective of the artist's work after her death in 1962.<ref name="TheBiography"/> The [[Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery|Tang Museum]] at Skidmore College holds a work by Weber Furlong which has been exhibited regionally since 1952. In the early 1950s Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, New York held solo exhibitions of the works of Weber Furlong for several years and she exhibited alongside the artist David Smith at the State Capital in Albany, New York.<ref name="TheBiography"/> The Ft. Edward Art Center hosted a solo exhibition in May 1994.<ref name="TheBiography"/> Starting in late September 2012 through early April 2013, The International Woman's Foundation in [[Marfa, Texas]] held a major retrospective of the works of Weber Furlong featuring over 75 unseen works and private belongings of the artist including her Victorian easel. The one woman show was held at the Iconic [[Building 98]] studio galleries along with a one-hour lecture by Professor Emeritus James K. Kettlewell, retired curator of the Hyde Collection.<ref name="BBSsum">{{cite web|url=http://bigbendnow.com/2012/08/marfa-city-council-onboard-for-american-modernism/ |publisher=Big Bend Sentinel|title=Marfa City Council onboard for American Modernism 2012-08-14|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Retrospective}}</ref><ref name="BBS2sum">{{cite web|url=http://bigbendnow.com/2012/12/weber-furlong-retrospective-extended-at-building-98/|publisher=Big Bend Sentinel|title=Weber Furlong retrospective extended at Building 98 May 14, 2013|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Retrospective}}</ref><ref name="avalanchesum1">{{cite web|url=http://www.alpineavalanche.com/news/article_07858480-fdb0-11e1-91cd-001a4bcf887a.html|publisher=The Alpine Avalanche Alpine, Texas|title=Weber Furlong Retrospective Begins September 27, 2102|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Retrospective Marfa, Texas}}</ref><ref name="avalanchesum">{{cite web|url=http://www.alpineavalanche.com/news/article_977ec73e-55b9-11e2-afc1-0019bb2963f4.html|publisher=The Alpine Avalanche Alpine, Texas|title=Weber Furlong Retrospective Held Over Tuesday, Thursday, January 3, 2013 9:23 am|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Retrospective Marfa, Texas}}</ref><ref name="cbssum">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs7kosa.com/news/details.asp?ID=37148|publisher=CBS 7|title=CBS Midland & Odessa 2006-12-14|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Retrospective}}</ref>[[File:Marfa Texas Weber Furlong Banner.jpg|thumb|left|300px|''Marfa, Texas Chinati Weekend'', 2012, [[Marfa, Texas]]]]
In Spring of 2012, Wilhelmina Weber Furlong became the subject of a documentary film based on the biography on the life of the popular early American woman modernist. Permanent displays of the work of Wilhelmina Weber Furlong are at the Hyde Collection in Glens Falls, New York and the [[Bolton Landing]], New York town history museum.<ref name="LOOKTVsum">{{cite web|url=http://www.looktvonline.com/americas-first-female-modern-artists-local-link-video|publisher=Look TV Glens Falls, New York|title=America's First Female Modern Artists Local Talk at Ten, August 7, 2012 |work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film & Biography}}</ref><ref name="MARFAPR2sum">{{cite web|url=http://marfapublicradio.org/blog/talk-at-ten/clint-weber-dr-james-kettlewell/|publisher=NPR Marfa, Texas|title=The Treasured Collection Talk at Ten, October 2, 2012 Clint Weber & James Kettlewell|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film & Biography}}</ref><ref>The Chronicle Glens Falls, New York</ref>
On August 7, 2012 the Crandall Public Library in [[Glens Falls]], New York hosted a documentary film crew and lecture on Wilhelmina Weber Furlong featuring James K. Kettlewell, Professor Emeritus Skidmore College and retired curator of the Hyde Collection, where they displayed one of Wilhelmina Weber Furlong's lost works.<ref name="LOOKTVsum"/><ref name="CRAsum">{{cite web|url=http://www.adirondackchamber.org/news/2012/08/07/get-to-know-the-artist-weber-furlong|publisher=Adirondack Chamber of Commerce|title=Get to know the artist Weber Furlong Glens Falls, NY, August 07, 2012|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film}}</ref><ref name="NCPRsum">{{cite web|url=http://www.northcountrypublicradio.org/news/story/20250/20120803/family-heirlooms-as-treasured-art|publisher=NPR New York|title=Family heirlooms as treasured art Bolton, NY, Aug 03, 2012|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film}}</ref><ref name="MARFAPRsum">{{cite web|url=http://marfapublicradio.org/blog/talk-at-ten/clint-webber/|publisher=NPR Marfa, Texas|title=The Treasured Collection Talk at Ten, July 19, 2012 |work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong Documentary Film & Biography}}</ref>
[[File:Weber Furlong Historic Marker.jpg|thumb|right| ''New York State Historic Marker'' located at City Hall in [[Glens Falls]], New York]]
On July 23, 2013 the [[Glens Falls, New York|City Glens Falls]], New York Common Council approved a resolution to place a New York State historical marker in downtown Glens Falls near City Hall. The resolution stated: "Weber Furlong (1878–1962) One of America's great and influential artists of the twentieth century, Weber Furlong was among the first to champion the Modern art movement. The final years of her life were spent in Glens Falls, where she lived and taught near this site at her Ridge Street studio until her death in 1962. ''Placed for the [[Warren County, New York|Warren County]] Bicentennial''."<ref name="poststarsum"/><ref name="hydesum">{{cite web|url=http://www.hydecollection.org/events_and_programs/Weber_Furlong_and_the_Origins_of_Modern_Art_374.htm|publisher=The Hyde Collection Glens Falls NY|title= Weber Furlong and the Origins of Modern Art October 6, 2013|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong on Lake George New York}}</ref><ref name="timewarnercablesum">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nH2y2Em6-4A|publisher=Time Warner Cable Albany NY|title= Weber Furlong Historic marker dedication|work=Wilhelmina Weber Furlong on Lake George New York}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.weberfurlong.com/ The Weber Furlong Foundation] * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/max-weber-papers-9331/more Detailed description of the Max Weber papers, 1902–2008 ...] * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/dorothy-dehner-papers-9686/more Detailed description of the Dorothy Dehner papers, 1920 ...] * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/ben-benn-papers-6209/more Detailed description of the Ben Benn papers, 1905–1993 ...] * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interviews-dorothy-dehner-13105 Oral history interviews with Dorothy Dehner, 1965 Oct.-1966 ...]
{{New Woman (late 19th century)}}

A '''word board''' or '''communications board''' is a simple means to help people who have lost the ability to speak. A word board may typically be provided to those recovering after a [[stroke]].<ref>[http://strokecenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/Recovering-After-a-Stroke.pdf] Stroke Centre - recovering after a atroke. Retrieved 18 November 2011</ref> To communicate, the user points at the relevant words, letters or symbols on the board. Typically the following are included:
'''Yes |No | (<big>☺</big>) |''' '''|Want| That'''
'''ABCD EFG'''
'''HIJK LMNOP'''
'''QRS ''X'' TUV'''
'''& WX ? YZ'''
'''Why|What|When|Where'''
There are now sophisticated electronic [[speech synthesis]] devices available for this purpose.
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Assistive technology]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2014}}
'''Young World Quiz''' is a live quiz contest held for students of classes 3 - 9 in [[India]]. It is part of [[The Hindu]]'s 'Newspapers in Education' initiative. It is according to The Hindu Young World" arguably the biggest live quiz show for middle and high school students in India." It is hosted by noted quiz master V. V. Ramanan,<ref>{{cite news|title=Your Quizmaster: V.V. RAMANAN|url=http://www.hindu.com/ywquiz/quizmaster.htm|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=June 21, 2011 }}</ref> and has completed 15 years.
== Winners == In 2002, it was held in eleven cities, with 3000 teams from over 1200 schools participating. The grand finale of The Hindu Young World Quiz 2012 was held at Chennai in Tamil Nadu, on December 7, 2012 and was won by [[Loyola School, Thiruvananthapuram|Loyola School]] of [[Trivandrum]].
In 2014, P. Adithya Sai and H. Aravind of class 5 from Sanghamitra School defeated their opponents by a huge margin in Hyderabad. In 2014, Kaveri Krishnan and Saraswathy Ashok of class 5 from Vidyodaya school made history by winning the first prize & as the defending champions, they were the 1st runners-up in the next year.
The sponsors were Firefox, Success notebooks etc. for the quiz in 2014.
In 2016, P.Adithya Sai and J.Shraman (Junior Category) of Sanghamitra School defeated their opponents with a whopping margin in the 16 edition of the quiz which was held in Hyderabad .
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.thehindu.com/features/kids/young-world-quiz/article5672940.ece Quiz published in the newspaper] * [http://www.youngworldquiz.in/ youngworldquiz.in]
* http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/schoolchildren-vie-for-coveted-title/article6673648.ece * http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/students-participate-in-young-world-quiz-with-zeal/article8178015.ece
